ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Dopant size dependent variable range hopping conduction in polyaniline nanorods

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Materials Research Laboratory, Dept. of Physics

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The present work investigates the electrical transport and dielectric relaxation of polyaniline (PAni) nanorods doped with organic camphorsulfonic acid (CSA) and inorganic hydrochloric acid (HCl) synthesized by interfacial polymerization technique. High resolution transmission electron micrographs (HRTEM) depict that initially spherical nuclei directionally grow into nanorods and CSA doped PAni produces more uniform and aligned structures. The electrical transport studies reveal that the CSA doped nanorods follow 1D Mott variable-range hopping (VRH), whereas the HCl doped nanorods exhibit 2D VRH conduction mechanism. The value of interchain charge transfer integral is found to be higher for smaller size HCl doped PAni than that for larger size CSA doped PAni. The resistivity measurements exhibit semiconducting behavior for both organic and inorganic dopants and the resistivity of the CSA doped nanorods is found to be smaller than that of the HCl doped nanorods. The dielectric relaxation studies suggest Debye type relaxation with a single relaxation peak for both the dopants and the relaxation time of the carriers of the CSA doped PAni nanorods is smaller than that of the HCl doped nanorods.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: In the present age conjugated conducting polymers are being most extensively studied because of their wide potential applications arising from their unique electrochemical, optical and mechanical properties [1, 2]. In undoped form, conducting polymers are semiconductors with an energy gap of Peierls–Mott origin [3]. Upon doping, the electrical conductivities of the conducting polymers can be increased from 10−10–10−5 to 102–103 S/cm, which covers the whole insulator–semiconductor–metal range. The conduction mechanism in conducting polymers is complex due to the disorder generated by the random nature of polymer chains and inhomogeneous doping that limits the conjugation length. It is widely believed that in disordered systems the charge transport takes place by the hopping of charge carriers between the localized states. The charge carriers of conducting polymers are solitons, polarons and bipolarons which are generated upon doping. Among the various conducting polymers [4], polyaniline (PAni) is unique because of its simple and reversible acid/base doping/dedoping chemistry enabling control over properties such as free volume, solubility, electrical conductivity, and optical activity [5]. One-dimensional nanostructures of conducting polymers such as nanowires, nanotubes and nanofibers have attracted intensive interest as they represent the smallest dimensional structures which can be used for different potential applications such as chemical sensors, actuators, light-emitting diodes, gas-separation membranes and secondary batteries, etc. [6]. Recently, various synthesis techniques, viz., hard template synthesis [7], self-assembly [8], electrochemical polymerization [9], interfacial polymerization [10], electro spinning technique [11], etc., have been used to synthesize different 1D conducting polymer nanostructures. Among these techniques, interfacial polymerization developed by Kaner’s group [12] is the latest to chemically synthesize polyaniline nanofibers in which the polymerization of aniline monomer is performed in an immiscible aqueous/organic biphasic system to separate the byproducts according to their solubility in the organic and aqueous phases.

Here we report a detailed experimental study of the electrical and dielectric properties of CSA and HCl doped polyaniline nanorods varying the dopant concentration. PAni nanorods have been synthesized by interfacial polymerization technique in an immiscible aqueous/organic biphasic system. The morphology, crystallinity, molecular interaction and transport properties have been investigated and compared for the two different dopants.

Section2.Heading: Materials
Section2.Para: Aniline monomer (Sigma-Aldrich), oxidant ferric chloride (FeCl3) (Merck), hydrochloric acid (HCl) (Qualigens Fine Chemicals) and camphorsulfonic acid (CSA) (Sigma-Aldrich) as dopants, methanol and acetone were used without any further treatment. Carbon tetrachloride (CCl4) and double distilled (DD) water were used as solvents.

Section2.Heading: Synthesis of PAni nanorods
Section2.Para: In the typical synthesis procedure FeCl3 (1.62 gm, 1 M) was added to 250 ml beaker, containing aqueous solution (10 ml) of 1.0 mol/L HCl and CSA, respectively, to form the aqueous phase. Aniline monomer (0.913 ml, 1 M) was dissolved in 10 ml of CCl4 to form the organic phase. Then the aqueous phase was carefully added along the side of the beaker into the organic phase to produce a clear interface of aqueous/organic solution. The initial formation of PAni nanorods most likely occurred at the aqueous/organic interface, and they subsequently migrated to the aqueous phase as the nanorods grow. The organic phase formed the lower layer, and as they grew, the nanorods migrated down into the aqueous phase [13]. After 48 h, the resulting PAni nanorods were filtered. The filtered out product was washed with DD water, methanol and acetone to remove excess acid, possible oligomers and organic solvent. Finally the powders were dried in a vacuum oven at room temperature for about 48 h. Three sets of samples were synthesized by taking the dopant concentration 1 M, 0.1 M and 0.001 M for both the dopants CSA and HCl.

Section2.Heading: Characterization
Section2.Para: The morphology of the PAni nanorods was examined with a JEM-2100, 200 kV, Jeol high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM). The powder samples for HRTEM were dispersed in DD water by using an ultrasonicator. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by using a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer (model MINIFLEX 200). Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was conducted using a Nicolet Impact I-410 FTIR spectrometer to characterize the molecular structure of the resulted PAni nanorods. The dried powders of PAni nanorods were pelletized for the resistivity and dielectric measurements. The resistivity measurements were carried out on rectangular shape samples (∼3.2×2.5×2.1 mm3) in the temperature range 50–300 K using the standard four-probe method using a 14 T/0.3 K PPMS. The dielectric measurements were conducted with a computer controlled impedance analyzer (HIOKI LCR Hi-Tester, model: 3532-50).

Section2.Heading: HRTEM studies
Section2.Para:
The HRTEM images of CSA and HCl doped PAni nanorods are shown in Fig. 1(a) and (b), respectively. The nanorods are formed due to the directional polymerization which takes place along π–π stacking direction as growth continues. It is observed from the HRTEM images that CSA doped spherical particles and nanorods are more uniformly distributed as compared to those of the HCl doped. The average diameter of the CSA doped nanoparticles is 27 nm and that of nanorods are around 18 nm, whereas for HCl doped nanorods they are 29 and 20 nm, respectively. The smaller diameter in case of CSA doped samples signifies more aligned nanostructures as compared to those of the HCl doped nanostructures [14].
Fig. 1
HRTEM images of (a) 1 M CSA and (b) 1 M HCl doped PAni showing the directional growth nanoparticles into nanorods

Figure 2(a) and (b) illustrates the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns of CSA and HCl doped PAni nanorods, respectively. For both the samples SAED patterns reveal the asymmetric growth of particles. The diffraction patterns exhibit a set of well-defined, however asymmetrically distributed, diffraction spots indicating an oriented crystallized structure. The figures also show spots on the circular rings indicating that the synthesized PAni nanorods consist of amorphous and crystalline phases.
Fig. 2
Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns of (a) CSA and (b) HCl doped PAni nanorods

Section2.Heading: X-ray diffraction studies
Section2.Para:
The X-ray diffraction patterns of 1 M CSA and HCl doped nanorods are shown in Fig. 3. A broad peak centered around 2θ=25∘ is observed for both the CSA and HCl doped nanorods which corresponds to the (110) planes of PAni [15]. This peak is attributed to the periodicity perpendicular to the polymer chains [16]. The d-spacing for CSA-doped nanorods is 3.7 Å, whereas for HCl doped it is found to be equal to 3.2 Å. Higher value of d-spacing in case of CSA doped PAni nanorods may be attributed to the bulky cycloaliphatic rings of CSA. The absence of the peak at 2θ=19.9∘ which is generally observed in bulk PAni may be due to the lack of ordering along the periodicity parallel to the polymer chains. The XRD patterns show that CSA doped PAni nanorods are more crystalline as compared to those of the HCl doped corroborating the HRTEM results. The increased intensity at 2θ=25∘ peak in CSA doped PAni nanorods is due to the improved π–π interchain stacking and ordering of the dopant molecules in the tunnels between the polymer chains. This suggests increased planar conformation with reduced torsion angles between the phenyl ring and the plane of the backbone, resulting in elongation of the effective conjugation length [17].
Fig. 3
X-Ray diffraction patterns of 1 M CSA and 1 M HCl doped PAni nanorods

Section2.Heading: FTIR analysis
Section2.Para:
FTIR is used to study the chain structure of polymers, which leads the way in interpreting the reaction of multifunctional monomers including rearrangements and isomerization. The interactions among different atoms or ions in the system induce changes in the electronic and vibrational levels of the atoms resulting in the influence of the spectrum [18]. Typical FTIR spectra of 1 M CSA and HCl doped PAni nanorods oxidized by FeCl3 are shown in Fig. 4. The band at 3241 cm−1 is assigned to the N–H stretching of the benzenoid units of the emeraldine form of PAni. The peaks at 1582 and 1500 cm−1 are assigned to C=C stretching of the quinoid and benzenoid rings, respectively. The peak in the range of 1145 cm−1 represents the C–H aromatic in-plane bending. The band characteristic of the electrically conductive form of doped polyaniline is observed at 1288 cm−1. This band is attributed to the stretching of the C–N+• polaron structure. The 687 cm−1 peak is assigned to the C–H out-of-plane deformations of the para disubstituted benzene rings. The band in the range of 838 cm−1 is identified as the out-of-plane bending of C–H bond in the 1, 4-disubstituted benzene ring [19]. All the characteristic peaks are observed for both CSA and HCl doped PAni nanorods. In case of HCl doped nanorods the C–H aromatic in-plane bending peak is observed at 1111 cm−1, whereas for CSA doped nanorods it shifted to 1145 cm−1. Shifting of peak towards the higher wavelength limit indicates that –SO3H group of CSA interacts more strongly as compared to that of Cl− ion of HCl. Moreover, the intensity of peaks is also higher in the CSA doped nanorods which indicates that CSA is a better dopant than HCl in terms of higher polaron mobility, less localized structure of polaron, higher conjugation length and high conductivity [20]. The intensity ratio of the two absorption bands due to the quinoid and benzenoid rings (I quinoid/I benzenoid) is indicative of the extent of oxidation state of the polymer, which reflects the relative content of the quinoid diimine and benzene ring structure. Generally the higher value of the intensity ratios (I quinoid/I benzenoid) indicates the smaller conductivity of PAni nanorods [21]. For CSA doped nanorods the intensity ratio is (I 1580/I 1504) 0.71 whereas that for the HCl doped nanorods is (I 1576/I 1476) 0.75. The smaller value of the intensity ratio indicates the enhancement of conductivity in case of CSA doped PAni nanorods as compared to that of HCl doped PAni nanorods, which is also confirmed from the resistivity measurements (next section).
Fig. 4
FTIR spectra of 1 M CSA and 1 M HCl doped PAni nanorods

Section2.Heading: Electrical transport
Section2.Para:
Electrical conductivity is related to the size and alignment of the polymer chains along the π bond. As the size decreases, undisturbed conjugation length increases leading to higher crystallinity and hence electrical conductivity. The resistivity ratio ρ
r =ρ (50 K)/ρ (300 K) is 4.54×102 and 6.98×102 for 1 M CSA and HCl doped PAni nanorods, respectively. Menon et al. [22] described that the metal–insulator (M–I) transition behavior is observed in PAni depending on the value of resistivity ratio (ρ
r ). They identified three different behaviors of PAni: (i) metallic region (ρ
r <2); (ii) critical region (2<ρ
r <6); and (iii) insulating region (ρ
r >6). Since the ratios of the samples in the present work are quite high, they fall in the insulating region. The electrical conductivity of a disordered system strongly depends on the extent of disorder present in the material. The extent of disorder is generally characterized in terms of the temperature dependence of resistivity, especially in terms of resistivity ratio ρ
r . The higher value of ρ
r implies the higher disorder of the samples [23]. Figure 5 shows the temperature dependence of resistivity for both CSA and HCl doped nanorods. The resistivity increases with the decrease of temperature, showing the semiconducting behavior in the entire temperature range of 50 K≤T≤300 K. The resistivity decreases for the dopants with increasing doping concentration as the number of carriers is enhanced. However, only the plots of 1 M dopant concentration for both CSA and HCl doped nanorods are presented as only the dopant size effect is being studied. The resistivity of CSA doped nanorods is smaller than that of the HCl doped, which may be ascribed to the increasing ordering of polymer chains due to the larger molecular size of CSA. The molecular size of the counter-ions strongly affects the conformation of PAni chains and the interchain coupling [24]. Larger CSA dopant counter-ions can restrict the twisting of PAni chains and keep the chains in a more expanded conformation, resulting in larger conjugation length, which leads to the higher conductivity of CSA doped PAni nanorods.
Fig. 5
Temperature dependence of resistivity of 1 M CSA and 1 M HCl doped PAni nanorods

The conduction of carriers in disordered materials is controlled by the hopping of charge carriers between the localized states near the Fermi level. When the Coulomb interaction of electrons is weak it is the Mott-VRH. In Mott-VRH, the resistivity expression is expressed as [25]:
1
$$ \rho = \rho_{0}\exp \biggl(\frac{T_{M}}{T}\biggr)^{1/1 + n} $$ where ρ 0 is the resistivity when T→∞, T
M is the characteristic Mott temperature, i.e., the energy needed for charge carriers’ hopping conduction which depends on the electronic structure and the energy distribution of the localized states, and n is the dimensionality n=1, 2 and 3 for 1D, 2D and 3D, respectively.

In order to understand the nature of conduction mechanism in more detail, we have calculated the reduced activation energy as the logarithmic derivative of ρ(T) [26]:
2
$$ W = - T\frac{d\ln \rho (T)}{dT} = - \frac{d\ln \rho}{d\ln T} $$ When the resistivity follows the temperature-dependent variable range hopping (VRH) model, the reduced activation energy expression takes the form
3
$$\begin{aligned} &{\log_{10}W(T) = A - x\log_{10}T} \\ &{\quad\mbox{where }A = x\log_{10}T_{M} + \log_{10}x} \end{aligned}$$ The value of x can be evaluated from the slope of the W versus T plots as shown in the inset of Fig. 6(a) and (b), which determines the dimension of hopping. From the slopes, the value of x is found to be equal to 0.55 and 0.38 for CSA and HCl doped nanorods, respectively. From the value of x, it is confirmed that the CSA doped nanorods follow 1D whereas the HCl doped nanorods follow the 2D variable range hopping (VRH) conduction mechanism. We have fitted the resistivity data by using the VRH model for 1D and 2D for CSA and HCl doped nanorods, respectively, as shown in Fig. 6(a) and (b). Figure 6(a) displays the lnρ vs. T −1/2 plots of CSA doped PAni nanorods and Fig. 6(b) depicts the lnρ vs. T −1/3 plots of HCl doped PAni nanorods. The larger molecular size of the CSA dopant restricts the twisting of polymer chains, as a result of which the charge transport can take place only in a particular direction giving rise to 1D VRH conduction in CSA doped nanorods. However, in HCl doped PAni smaller size of Cl− dopant ions cannot prevent the polymer chains from twisting, so the electronic wave function of the charge carrier gets extended into two dimensions giving rise to the 2D VRH charge transport mechanism in case of HCl doped nanorods.
Fig. 6
(a) lnρ vs. T −1/2 plot of 1 M CSA doped nanorods, (b) lnρ vs. T −1/3 plot of 1 M HCl doped nanorods

The overlapping of π-electron wave functions of conjugated polymers exhibits a quasi one-dimensional (1D) anisotropy and the charge conduction process is controlled by the intra-chain conjugation length, inter-chain packing and their limitation by various kinds of disorders [27]. In some parts of the material, the applied field is directed with some angle to the chain direction and interchain hopping takes place between different chains [28]. The charge transfer integral is the efficiency of charge hopping by overlapping of two electronic levels between two sites. Higher value of the interchain transfer integral signifies larger hopping in-between the chains rather than that along the chain. Assuming that all the electron wave functions decay exponentially, the interchain charge transfer integral can be given by the following equation [29]:
4
$$ t_{ \bot} = \frac{2}{3}\frac{e^{2}}{\varepsilon a}\frac{r}{a}\exp (-r /a) $$ where r is the d-spacing (calculated from XRD), ε=4 and a is the radius of π electrons on the carbon atom which is twice the value of the Bohr radius (1.06 Å).

The calculated interchain charge transfer integrals for CSA and HCl doped nanorods are 0.021 and 0.029 eV, respectively. Smaller value of interchain charge transfer integral for CSA doped nanorods suggests that interchain charge transfer hopping in case of CSA doped nanorods is smaller as compared to that for HCl doped leading to the 1D VRH conduction in case of CSA doped nanorods.

The expression for characteristic Mott temperature (T
M ) and hopping distance (R hop) for the 1D and 2D variable range hopping (VRH) can be expressed as:
5
$$\begin{aligned} \begin{aligned} &{T_{M} = \frac{16}{L_{C}N(E_{F})K_{B}Z},} \\ &{ R_{\mathrm{hop}} = \biggl[\frac{L_{C}}{\pi TK_{B}N(E_{F})} \biggr]^{1/2} \quad\mbox{for }1\mathrm{D}} \end{aligned} \end{aligned}$$ and
6
$$ \begin{aligned} &T_{M} = \frac{3}{K_{B}N(E_{F})dL_{C}^{2}}, \\ &R_{\mathrm{hop}} = L_{C}\biggl(\frac{T_{M}}{T} \biggr)^{1/3}\quad \mbox{for }2\mathrm{D} \end{aligned} $$ where L
C is the localization length, N(E
F ) is the density of states at the Fermi level, Z is the number of nearest-neighbor chains which is 4 for polyaniline, and d is the thickness of the sample. The values of hopping distances are calculated by taking the localization length equal to 10 Å at T=100 K [30, 31] and the fitting parameters ρ 0 and characteristic Mott-temperature T
M are calculated and tabulated in Table 1.
Table 1

Section2.Heading: Dielectric permittivity
Section2.Para:
Dielectric properties describe the ability of an electrical medium to be polarized by an applied electric field. When a dielectric medium is placed in an applied electric field, the electric charges shift from their equilibrium positions causing dielectric polarization. The permittivity is expressed as [32]:
7
$$ \varepsilon^{ *} (\omega ) = \frac{D_{0}}{E_{0}}(\cos \omega \tau - j \sin \omega \tau ) $$ where D 0 and E 0 are the amplitudes of the electric displacement and electric field, respectively; τ is the relaxation time and ω=2πf, f being the measuring frequency. The dielectric behavior is generally described by the complex permittivity where the real and imaginary parts represent the storage and loss of energy in each cycle of the applied electric field. Figure 7 shows the frequency dependence of real part of permittivity of 1 M CSA and HCl doped PAni nanorods at room temperature. It is observed for both the cases that ε′ decreases with increasing frequency. There are no permanent dipoles in conducting polymers, the charge carriers in these polymers are strongly trapped and the localized short range motion of these carriers under the application of external alternating field can act as ‘effective’ electric dipole [33]. The nature of dielectric permittivity related to oscillating free dipoles in an ac field may be described as follows: at low frequencies (ω≪1/τ, τ is the relaxation time), the dipoles follow the field and ε′ approaches the value of static dielectric constant ε
s . With the increase in frequencies (ω<1/τ), dipoles start to lag behind the field and hence ε′ decreases slightly. At very high frequencies (ω≫1/τ), dipoles can no longer follow the electric field and ε′ approaches ε ∞. The increment in dielectric permittivity with decrease in frequency suggesting that the PAni nanorods exhibit strong interfacial polarization at sufficiently low frequency. The strong low frequency dispersion of ε′ observed in both the PAni samples is the characteristic of the disordered conducting polymeric systems [17].
Fig. 7
Variation of real permittivity (ε′) of 1 M CSA and 1 M HCl doped PAni nanorods at room temperature

The frequency dependence of imaginary permittivity ε″ for 1 M CSA and HCl doped PAni nanorods is plotted in Fig. 8(a) and (b), respectively. The ε″ versus frequency curve of low conducting materials usually consists of a conductivity region at low frequencies and a dielectric relaxation part at higher frequencies [10]. Separation of the relaxation processes from the conductivity contribution can be achieved by fitting procedure based on the semi-empirical Havriliak–Negami equation [34]:
8
$$ \varepsilon^{\prime\prime} = \frac{\sigma_{dc}}{\varepsilon_{0}\omega^{ - s}} + \frac{\Delta \varepsilon '\sin (\beta \phi )}{[1 + 2(\omega \tau )^{1 - \alpha} \sin (\pi \alpha /2) + (\omega \tau )^{2(1 - \alpha )}]^{\beta /2}} $$ where s is the fitting parameter which is 1 in ideal cases and smaller in more complex conductivity mechanisms, Δε′=ε 0−ε ∞ is the dielectric relaxation strength. The first term of Eq. (8) represents the contribution of dc conductivity to the ε″ losses and the second term is the Havriliak–Negami empirical relation. α and β are the dispersion parameters, where α (0<α<1) and β (0<β<1) describe the symmetric and asymmetric broadening of the relaxation time (τ) distributions, respectively. The ε″ data have been fitted to Eq. (8) and the best fit is shown in Fig. 8(a) and (b) for α∼0 and β∼1. The values α=0 and β=1 indicate that the PAni nanorods nearly follow the Debye relaxation model with single relaxation peak and the relaxation time is symmetrically distributed. As can be seen from the figures the dielectric relaxation contributes more to the ε″ for HCl doped PAni while the conductivity relaxation contributes more in case of CSA doped PAni. The higher conductivity contribution for CSA doped PAni is also corroborated by resistivity measurements. The dielectric relaxation arises due to the hopping of the localized carriers under the application of an ac field [35]. At low frequencies charge transport can occur freely without any strong ‘pinning’ and the contribution of dc conductivity is larger. As frequency increases the charge carriers are strongly ‘pinned’ at their localized sites and the carrier hopping is sufficiently reduced. The CSA molecules being bulky in size enhance the chain ordering in PAni enhancing the carrier hopping and hence the conductivity contribution is greater than that of HCl doped PAni.
Fig. 8
Frequency-dependent imaginary permittivity (ε″) plot of (a) 1 M CSA and (b) 1 M HCl doped nanorods at room temperature. The solid line is the best fit according to Eq. (8). The dashed line shows the conductivity contribution and the dotted line shows the contribution from Havriliak–Negami function

Section2.Heading: Modulus formalism
Section2.Para:
Additional information about the dielectric behavior of the nanorods can be obtained from the modulus formalism. The complex electric modulus is a convenient formalism to eliminate the electrode polarization effects in dielectric relaxation measurements of the conjugated polymers, from which the information about the conductivity relaxation behavior can be determined. The complex modulus is defined by the complex permittivity according to the relation given by Macedo et al. [36]. Real and imaginary parts of M′ and M″ of the electric modulus can be obtained from ε′ and ε″ as:
9
$$\begin{aligned} M^{ *} =& \frac{1}{\varepsilon^{ *}} = \frac{1}{\varepsilon ' - j\varepsilon ''} = \frac{\varepsilon '}{\varepsilon '^{2} + \varepsilon ''^{2}} + j\frac{\varepsilon ''}{\varepsilon '^{2} + \varepsilon ''^{2}} \\ =& M' + jM'' \end{aligned}$$ The frequency dependence of real part of modulus M′ is shown in Fig. 9. It is observed from the figure that M′ shows an asymptotic value of M′, i.e. it tends to higher value (M′) at high frequency and tends to zero at lower frequency, which indicates the negligible electrode polarization contribution to M′ [36].
Fig. 9
Real modulus (M′) vs. frequency plot of 1 M CSA and 1 M HCl doped nanorods at room temperature

The frequency dependence of imaginary part of modulus M″ is plotted in Fig. 10. It is observed that a relaxation peak appears for both the CSA and HCl doped PAni nanorods. For CSA doped nanorods the peak shifts towards higher frequency compared to the HCl doped nanorods indicating smaller relaxation time and enhanced dc conductivity according to the following equation [37]:
10
$$ \sigma_{dc} = \frac{\omega \varepsilon_{0}}{M} $$ The imaginary modulus is fitted to the Debye model with single relaxation time using the following equation [36]:
11
$$ M'' = \frac{M_{\infty} M_{S}(M_{\infty} - M_{S})\omega \tau}{ (M_{\infty}^{2} + M_{S}^{2}\omega^{2}\tau^{2})} $$ where M
s is value of M″ when ω→0 and M ∞ when ω→∞. The peak frequency ω max in the M″ vs. ω spectra represents the transition from short-range to long-range mobility at decreasing frequency along conductivity paths. The peak towards the low frequency represents the range of frequencies in which charge carriers can move over long distances. The high frequency side of the M″ peak indicates the range of frequencies in which charge carriers are spatially confined to their potential wells and can make only localized motion within the wells. The peak frequency ω max is the characteristic of conductivity relaxation and defines the most probable relaxation time by ω max τ
M =1. The most probable relaxation time for CSA and HCl doped PAni is calculated and tabulated in Table 1. The smaller value of most probable relaxation time in case of CSA doped PAni nanorods reveals that the charge carriers in CSA doped PAni relax faster than those in HCl doped PAni.
Fig. 10
Imaginary modulus (M″) plot of 1 M CSA and 1 M HCl doped PAni nanorods. The solid line represents the best fit according to Eq. (11)

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: PAni nanorods doped with CSA and HCl have been synthesized by interfacial polymerization technique at different dopant concentrations. HRTEM results show that initially spherical nanoparticles nucleate which grow directionally into nanorods. The XRD patterns reveal that the CSA doped PAni nanorods are more crystalline than those of the HCl doped. The temperature variation of resistivity shows semiconducting behavior in the entire temperature range of 50–300 K. The resistivity of HCl doped nanorods is higher than that of CSA doped, which may be attributed to the higher disorder in HCl doped nanorods. The conduction in CSA doped nanorods occurs by 1D VRH of carriers whereas in case of HCl doped nanorods the conduction mechanism is 2D VRH. From the dielectric permittivity spectra it is observed that both real and imaginary parts of dielectric permittivity increase with decrease in frequency. From the permittivity analysis it can be concluded that the conductivity contribution is more for CSA doped nanorods. At higher frequency the real modulus spectra show dispersive behavior which is the characteristics of disordered materials. From the imaginary modulus plot the relaxation time for the CSA doped nanorods is found to be smaller as compared to that for the HCl doped PAni nanorods.
